notes:
1. Newton's Second Law for Rotation

Newton's Second Law for linear motion ($F = ma$) has a direct analog for rotational motion. It relates the net external torque (or moment) acting on a body to its angular acceleration.

2. The Equation

For a rigid body rotating about a fixed axis passing through its center of mass (G):

$$ \sum M_G = I_G \alpha $$
  • $\sum M_G$: The sum of all external moments (torques) about the center of mass.
  • $I_G$: The mass moment of inertia of the body about the center of mass.
  • $\alpha$: The angular acceleration of the body (in radians/s²).

If the body is rotating about a fixed axis (O) that does not pass through the center of mass, it is often convenient to sum moments about the fixed axis:

$$ \sum M_O = I_O \alpha $$

solvedExamples.question: A constant torque of 20 N·m acts on a flywheel with a mass moment of inertia of 4 kg·m². What is the angular acceleration of the flywheel?
solvedExamples.explanation: Use the rotational analog of Newton's Second Law: $\tau = I\alpha$ (or $\sum M = I\alpha$). Rearranging for angular acceleration: $\alpha = \tau / I = 20 \text{ N·m} / 4 \text{ kg·m²} = 5 \text{ rad/s²}$.

solvedExamples.question: If the moment of inertia of a rotating body is doubled while the applied torque remains constant, what happens to the angular acceleration?
solvedExamples.explanation: From the equation $\alpha = \tau / I$, angular acceleration is inversely proportional to the moment of inertia. If $I$ doubles, $\alpha$ becomes half of its original value.
